36 Vita sancti Brendani Abbatis de H&ydot;bernia.
SEint b&rrot;endan Brendan þe holi man &punctelev; was here of ovre londe
Monek he was of harde liue &punctelev; as ich me under&slong;tonde
Of fa&slong;tingue and oþur penaunce inov &punctelev; and Abbot he was þere
Of a þousend Monekes &punctelev; þat alle under him were
hit bifeol in a da&ydot; &punctelev; as o&rrot;e louerdes wille was
Þat ber&ydot;n*. [al. barint] an oþur Abbot &punctelev; to him cam bi cas
Seint b&rrot;endan Brendan him bisouȝte anon &punctelev; him don onder&slong;tonde
Ant tellen him ȝwat he hadde iseiȝe &punctelev; aboute in oþur londe
Þis guode man þo he iheo&rrot;de þis &punctelev; sichingues he made inowe
Ant in grete þouȝte bigan fo&rrot;to weope &punctelev; and fel adoun isuowe
bitwene his armes seint b&rrot;endan Brendan &punctelev; þis holie man op nam
& cu&slong;te him fa&slong;te & cride on him &punctelev; al fo&rrot;to is wit him cam
Fader he seide par charite &punctelev; oþur red þov mo&slong;t take
hidere þou come fo&rrot; ovre solas &punctelev; and nouȝt su&ydot;ch deol to make
tel us ȝwat þou ha&slong;t iseiȝe &punctelev; aboute as þou ha&slong;t iwend
In þe .se. of Occean01 &punctelev; as o&rrot;e louerd þe hath isend
Nou is þe .se. [of] Occean01 &punctelev; grette&slong;t and me&slong;t also:
heo goth aboute al þe wo&rrot;ld &punctelev; and alle oþere cometh þerto
So þat berin þis olde man &punctelev; riȝt of is heo&rrot;te grounde
Al weopinde he hem tolde &punctelev; ȝwat he hadde ifounde
he seide he*. [al. ic] hadde a wel guod sone &punctelev; and Mernok was is name
A Monek he was as we beoth &punctelev; and man of grete fame
his heo&rrot;te him ȝaf fo&rrot;to wende &punctelev; into a p&rrot;iue &slong;tude and &slong;tille
Þare he miȝte beo al one &punctelev; to aserui godes Godes wille
So þat bi mine wille he wende &punctelev; ase ich it telle ov
to an &ydot;le fer in þe se &punctelev; þat delitable was inov
biside þe Monta&ydot;ne of &slong;tones &punctelev; þat is couth wel wide
Þe Monek likede þare wel &punctelev; and longue gan þare abide
And hadde þare under him &punctelev; Monekes mani on
Þo ich heo&rrot;de tellen þat &punctelev; þuderward ich gan gon
So þat in auision &punctelev; o&rrot;e suete louerd him sende
Þat aȝen me are ich to him come &punctelev; þre Io&rrot;neies he wende
And in a schip we duden us sone &punctelev; and A&slong;tward euere kenden
In þe .se. of Occean01 &punctelev; as o&rrot;e louerd is grace us sende
toward þe e&slong;t so fer we wenden &punctelev; þat we comen ate la&slong;te
In su&ydot;þe þu&ydot;&slong;ter &slong;tude &punctelev; and clouden us ouerca&slong;te
Al ane tide of þe da&ydot;e &punctelev; we weren in deo&rrot;khede
Ate la&slong;te o&rrot;e suete louerd &punctelev; fo&rrot;þere us gan lede
So þat we iseiȝen a newe lond &punctelev; þuderward o&rrot;e schip d&rrot;ov
briȝtto&rrot;e it þouȝte þane þe sonne &punctelev; Io&ydot;e þare was inov
Of treon and herbes þikke jnovȝ &punctelev; biset in eche side
And of suete p&rrot;eciouse &slong;tones &punctelev; þat b&rrot;iȝtte sch&ydot;nen and wide
Euerech herbe was ful of floures &punctelev; and ech treo was ful of fru&ydot;t
bote it were in heuene &punctelev; nas neuere mo&rrot;e du&ydot;t
ÞareInne with Io&ydot;e and blisse Inovȝ &punctelev; longue we duden iwende
Ȝeot us þouȝte lu&ydot;tel ȝw&ydot;le &punctelev; ne miȝte we finde non ende
So þat we comen to a watur &punctelev; cler and b&rrot;iȝt Inovȝ
þat euere framward þe e&slong;t &punctelev; toward þe we&slong;t it d&rrot;ovȝ
We &slong;toden and biheolden aboute &punctelev; fo&rrot; we ne miȝten ouer iwende
Þare cam to us a ȝong ȝomman &punctelev; swiþe fair and hende
And welcomede us euerechone &punctelev; wel mildeliche and swete
he nemnede euerech is riȝtte name &punctelev; and faire gan us grete
And seide þat we ouȝten*. [al. ȝe aȝte] Ihesu cri&slong;t &punctelev; þonki su&ydot;þe wel with riȝte
Þat schewez eov is p&rrot;iuete &punctelev; and also of is miȝte
Þis is þat lond þat he wole &punctelev; ȝu&ydot;t are þe wo&rrot;ldes ende
[his dernelinges an erþe ȝ&ydot;ue &punctelev; ȝ h&ydot;der he schal[heo scholle on the margin.] wende.[This verse added b&ydot; a later hand in the text and on the margin.]
Þis lond is half in þusse half &punctelev; ase ȝe iseoz wel wide
And biȝeonde þe watere haluendel &punctelev; al bi þat oþur side
Þat watur ne mowe ȝe passi nouȝt &punctelev; þat oþur del to seo
Fo&rrot;*. [al. om.] here ȝe habbez al a ȝer &punctelev; meteles ibeo
Þat ȝe ne eten ne d&rrot;onken &punctelev; ne slepen nouȝt with e&ydot;ȝe
Ne chele ne hete ne greuede ev nouȝt &punctelev; noþur lowe ne heiȝe
Þis*. [al. Fo&rrot; þis] is o&rrot;e louerdes p&rrot;iue &slong;tude &punctelev; and þo&rrot;uȝ him it is þus liȝt
Þarefo&rrot;e it is [her] euere da&ydot; &punctelev; and neueremo&rrot;e niȝt
ȝif Adam aȝein godes Godes he&slong;te &punctelev; ne hadde noþing misdo
hereInne he hadde ȝu&ydot;t ibeo &punctelev; and is ofsp&rrot;ung also
Ȝe ne mowen no leng here bileue &punctelev; aȝen ȝe moten fare;[Here 2 fol. are to&rrot;n out in the MS. I suppl&ydot; the gap from MS. Harl. 2277.]
[Þeȝ hit ne þenche ȝou bote a while &punctelev; ȝe habbeþ ibeo her ȝare. [Harl. 2277 folio 42b]
Þat so*. [al. So þat] he b&rrot;ouȝte ous in oure schip &punctelev; & faire his leue nom
& þo*. [MS. þe] we were hamward in þe see &punctelev; we nu&slong;te whar he bicom
Aȝeward he wende aȝen oure wille &punctelev; þat ofþoȝte ous so&rrot;e &ydot;nouȝ
Aȝen to þis oþer monekes &punctelev; þis schip wel euene d&rrot;ouȝ
¶Þis monekes vrne aȝen ous &punctelev; þo hi ous miȝte iseo
& so&rrot;i were & wroþe &ydot;nouȝ &punctelev; þat we hadde so longe ibeo
we seide hem þat we hadde ibeo &punctelev; in gret io&ydot;e & fe&slong;te
Bifo&rrot;e þe ȝates of para&ydot;s &punctelev; in þe lond of bihe&slong;te
Þat oure suete louerd haþ bihote &punctelev; hem þat he loueþ her
Þer is euere dai & neuere niȝt &punctelev; & euere liȝt su&ydot;þe cler
¶Certes quaþ þis monekes &punctelev; þis we mowe iseo
Bi þe suete sm&ydot;l of ȝou &punctelev; þat ȝe habbeþ þer ibeo
¶Þo seint Brendan ihurde þis &punctelev; he þoȝte & &slong;tod &slong;tille
[he þoȝte fondi mo&rrot;e herof &punctelev; ȝif it were godes Godes wille.][This verse om. in H. is taken from Ashm.]
he wende aboute his monekes &punctelev; & tuelue out he nom
Þat he tri&slong;te to me&slong;t of alle &punctelev; whan eni neode him com
Þuse he nom in consail &punctelev; & in p&rrot;iueite [hem] sede:
[I þenche do a p&rrot;iue þing &punctelev; þerof ȝe mote me rede
To seche þat lond of bihe&slong;te &punctelev; ȝif god God wolde ous þuder lede.][These 2 v. om. in H.]
Siggeþ what ȝoure consail is &punctelev; to do such a dede
Leoue fader quaþ þis oþere &punctelev; oure wille we habbeþ fo&rrot;sake
¶Oure freond & al oure oþer god God &punctelev; & clanliche to þe itake
& whan al oure dede is on þe &punctelev; & þu wolt þat hit beo
we schulle bliþeliche wiþ þe wende &punctelev; godes Godes grace to seo
So þat hi fa&slong;te fourti dawes &punctelev; & gret penance dude also
& bede ȝurne oure louerdes grace &punctelev; þulke ve&ydot;age to do
hi leten hem diȝte a gret schip &punctelev; & aboue hit albi[MS. abbi]ca&slong;te
wiþ bolehuden &slong;tronge &ydot;nou &punctelev; &ydot;nailed þerto fa&slong;te
& siþþe ipiched al abou[t]e &punctelev; þat þe water [in] necome. [Harl. 2277 folio 43]
hi wende to here b&rrot;eþeren &punctelev; & wel faire here leue nome
And siþþe in oure louerdes name &punctelev; to schipe wende anon
here b&rrot;eþeren þat bih&ydot;nde were &punctelev; so&rrot;i were echon
& þo hi were in þe schip &punctelev; after þer come go[al. om.] tuo
& bede fa&slong;te þat hi mo&slong;te &punctelev; þane wei mid hem go
Ȝe mowe wel quaþ seint b&rrot;endan Brendan &punctelev; ac ȝoure on schal atta[n] ende
Repenti er he come aȝe &punctelev; & al quic to helle wende
Þider*. [al. vo&rrot;þ him] wende þis holi man &punctelev; whoder oure louerd hem sende
& þis tuei monekes þat come la&slong;t &punctelev; also wiþ hem wende
¶In þe grete see of occian &punctelev; fo&rrot;þ hi rewe fa&slong;te
& tri&slong;te alto oure louerdes grace &punctelev; & noþing nere aga&slong;te
Þe see d&rrot;of here schip after wil &punctelev; þe w&ydot;nd was gret &ydot;nouȝ
As þe w&ydot;nd hem d&rrot;of e&slong;t fo&rrot;þ &punctelev; wel euene þe schip him d&rrot;ouȝ
Euene aȝe þat þe sonne ariseþ &punctelev; amidsomeres da&ydot;
Nou nu&slong;te non of hem whar he was &punctelev; ne no lond he nesa&ydot;
Euene fo&rrot;þriȝt fourti da&ydot;es &punctelev; þe w&ydot;nd hem d&rrot;of fa&slong;te:
So þat hi seȝe in þe no&rrot;þside &punctelev; a gret &ydot;lle[r. &ydot;le] atte la&slong;te
Of harde roche & gret &ydot;nou &punctelev; in þe see wel heȝe
Þreo da&ydot;es hi wende þeraboute &punctelev; er hi miȝte come þerneȝe
¶A lute hauene hi*. [MS. he] fonde þo &punctelev; alond hi wende þere
hi wende alond as maskede*. [al. masid] men &punctelev; hi nu&slong;te whar hi were
Þer com go a wel fair hound &punctelev; as hit were hem to here
At seint Brendanes fet he ful adoun &punctelev; & makede him faire chere
¶ Beau freres quaþ seint b&rrot;endan Brendan &punctelev; ȝe neþo&rrot;e noþing d&rrot;ede
Ich wot þis is a messager &punctelev; þe riȝte wei ous to lede
Þis hound ladde þis holi man &punctelev; to an halle fair &ydot;nouȝ
Gret & &slong;tarc & su&ydot;þe noble &punctelev; euene in he d&rrot;ouȝ
Þis monekes fonde in þis halle &punctelev; bo&rrot;d & cloþ isp&rrot;ad
& b&rrot;ed & fisch þervppe &ydot;nouȝ &punctelev; þer nas non þat nas glad
hi sete adoun & ete fa&slong;te &punctelev; fo&rrot; hem lu&slong;te wel þerto
Beddes þer were al ȝare &ydot;maked &punctelev; er here soper were ido:
After here soper to bedde hi wende &punctelev; to re&slong;ten hem as þe wise
Þo hi hadde alle islepe &ydot;nouȝ &punctelev; sone hi gonne arise
& wende to here schip &punctelev; as hi hadde er ibeo
In þe see wel longe hi were &punctelev; er hi miȝte lond iseo
¶Þo hi seȝe*. [r. seȝe hi] as bi þoþer side &punctelev; an &ydot;lle fair &ydot;nouȝ
Grene & [wiþ] wel fair lese. &punctelev; þiderward here schip d&rrot;ouȝ
Þo hi come on þis faire lond &punctelev; & bihulde aboute wide [Harl. 2277 folio 43b]
Þe faire&slong;te scheep þat miȝte beo &punctelev; hi seȝe in eche side
A scheep was grettere þan an oxe &punctelev; whittere ne miȝte non beo
Gret io&ydot;e hi hadde in here hurte &punctelev; þat hi miȝte þis iseo
Þer com*. [al. þo com þer] go a wel fair man &punctelev; & grette hem wiþ faire chere
& seide ȝe beoþ hider icome &punctelev; þer ȝe neuere nere
¶Þis is icliped þe lond of scheep &punctelev; fo&rrot; scheep wel faire her beoþ
Mochele & white & grete &ydot;nouȝ &punctelev; as ȝe aldai iseoþ
Fairere hi beoþ þan ȝoure scheep &punctelev; & grettere vn&ydot;liche
Fo&rrot; murie weder is her &ydot;nouȝ &punctelev; & lese su&ydot;þe riche
her nis neuere w&ydot;nter non &punctelev; fo&rrot; her nis non[al. ne non hei] ifounde
Ac hi eteþ þerbes nue &punctelev; as hi sp&rrot;ingeþ of þe g[ro]unde
Ne me ne gadereþ noȝt of here mulc &punctelev; þat hi scholde þe wo&rrot;se beo
¶Fo&rrot; þis þing & meni oþer &punctelev; þe bet hi mowe iþeo
To a &slong;tede ȝe schulle hunne wende &punctelev; þurf oure louerdes grace
Þat is foweles para&ydot;s &punctelev; a wel io&ydot;ful place
Þer ȝe schulle þis e&slong;ter beo &punctelev; & þis witsonedai also
Wendeþ fo&rrot;þ a godes Godes name &punctelev; þat þis ve&ydot;age were ido
SEint Brendan & his b&rrot;eþeren &punctelev; to schipe wende anon
& rue fo&rrot;þ fa&slong;te in þe see &punctelev; wiþ tempe&slong;t meni on
So þat hi seȝe in anoþer side &punctelev; an &ydot;lle gret &ydot;nouȝ
here schip þurf godes Godes grace &punctelev; þiderwardes d&rrot;ouȝ
Þo hit cam alme&slong;t þerto &punctelev; vpe þe roche hit gan ride
Þat hit ne miȝte noȝt to þe &ydot;le come &punctelev; ac bileuede biside
Þis monekes wende*. [al. wode] vp to þis &ydot;le &punctelev; ac seint b&rrot;endan Brendan noȝt
Þis monekes gonne makie here mete &punctelev; of þat hi hadde ib&rrot;oȝt
hi makede fur & soden hem fisch &punctelev; in a caud&rrot;oun fa&slong;te
Er þis fisch were isode [Inouȝ] &punctelev; somdel hi were aga&slong;te
Fo&rrot; þo þis fur was þurfhot &punctelev; þe &ydot;le quakede anon
& wiþ gret eir hupte al vp &punctelev; þis monekes d&rrot;adde echon
[& þe wei toward ho&rrot; schip &punctelev; ech after oþer nom
God leue&slong;t hem þoȝte he was &punctelev; þat sone&slong;t þuder com.][om. in H.]
hi bihulde hou þe &ydot;le &punctelev; in þe see wende fa&slong;te
& as a quic þing hupte vp & doun &punctelev; & þat fur fram him ca&slong;te
he suam mo&rrot;e þan tuei m&ydot;le &punctelev; while þis fur ila&slong;te
Þe monekes iseȝe þe fur wel longe &punctelev; & were so&rrot;e aga&slong;te
hi cride ȝurne on seint b&rrot;endan Brendan &punctelev; what þe wonder were
Beoþ &slong;tille" quaþ þis gode man &punctelev; fo&rrot; noȝt ȝe nabbe[al. habbeþ] fere
Ȝe weneþ þat hit beo an &ydot;le &punctelev; ac ȝe þencheþ amis
hit is a fisch of þis grete see &punctelev; þe grette&slong;te þat þer is
Ia&slong;toni he is icleped &punctelev; & fondeþ niȝt & dai [Harl. 2277 folio 44]
To pulte his tail in his mouþ &punctelev; ac fo&rrot; gretnisse he nemai
Fo&rrot;þ hi rue in þe see &punctelev; euene we&slong;t wel fa&slong;te
Þreo da&ydot;es er hi seȝe lond &punctelev; hi were somdel aga&slong;te
¶Þo seȝen hi a wel fair lond &punctelev; of floures þikke &ydot;nouȝ
wel glade hi were þo hi seȝe &punctelev; þat here schip þider d&rrot;ouȝ
In þis faire lond hi wende &punctelev; lengere þan ic telle
So þat hi fonde in a place &punctelev; a su&ydot;þe noble welle
Bi þe welle &slong;tod a treo &punctelev; b&rrot;od & round &ydot;nouȝ
Foweles white & faire &ydot;nouȝ &punctelev; were in euerech[al. so þicke were in ech] bouȝ
Þat vneþe eni leef &punctelev; hi miȝte þeron iseo
Þer was io&ydot;e & blisse &ydot;nouȝ &punctelev; to lokie on suche o treo
¶Seint Brendan fo&rrot; io&ydot;e wep &punctelev; & sat adoun akneo
And bad oure louerd schowi him &punctelev; what such a cas miȝte beo
Þo fleȝ þer vp alute fowel &punctelev; þo he gan to fleo[al. & toward him gan te]
As a fiþele his w&ydot;nges furde &punctelev; þo he to himward gan teo.[al. þo he gan to fleo]
Murie[re] In&slong;trument neuere nas &punctelev; þan*. [MS. þat] his w&ydot;ngen were
he bihuld seint b&rrot;endan Brendan &punctelev; wiþ wel faire chere
Ich hote [þe] seide seint b&rrot;endan Brendan &punctelev; if þu ert messager
Þat þu sigge me what [þu] ert &punctelev; & what ȝe doþ her
Þeȝ hit þoȝte aȝe cunde &punctelev; þis fowel ansuerede anon
We were he seide sumt&ydot;me was &punctelev; angles in heuene echon
As*. [r. ac sone so] sone as we were &ydot;maked &punctelev; oure mai&slong;ter was so p&rrot;out
Lucefer fo&rrot; his fairhede &punctelev; þat he ful sone out
& mid him also meni on &punctelev; as here dede was
¶& we fulle also adoun &punctelev; ac fo&rrot; no s&ydot;nne hit nas
fo&rrot;*. [MS. Ac fo&rrot;] noþing þat we assentede &punctelev; to his foule vnriȝt
Bote soulement fo&rrot;to schewe &punctelev; oure louerdes suete[al. suete louerdes] miȝt
Ne we ne beoþ her in p&ydot;ne non &punctelev; ac in io&ydot;e &ydot;nouȝ we beoþ
And somdel oure suete louerdes &punctelev; miȝte we seoþ
& bi þe vrþe we fleoþ &punctelev; & bi þe lifte also
As gode angles & liþere ek &punctelev; riȝt is fo&rrot;to do
Þe gode [fo&rrot;]to do men god God &punctelev; þe liþer liþere makieþ
¶&sonedai þat is dai of re&slong;t &punctelev; such fo&rrot;me we takeþ &punctelev; [MS. makeþ]
Þe fo&rrot;me of suche white foweles &punctelev; as þu miȝt iseo
[&] honureþ god God þat ous makede &punctelev; her on þis b&rrot;ode treo
Tuelfmonþ hit [is] ipassed nou &punctelev; þat ȝe gonne out wende
& alle þis six ȝer ȝe schulle fare &punctelev; er ȝe schulle[al. om.] b&rrot;inge ȝoure wille to ende
Fo&rrot; whan ȝe habbeþ iwend soue ȝer &punctelev; oure louerd wole ȝou sende [Harl. 2277 folio 44b]
A siȝt þat ȝe habbeþ longe isoȝt &punctelev; anon after þe soue ȝeres ende
Eche ȝer ȝe schulle her mid ous &punctelev; holde e&slong;terfe&slong;te
As ȝe nou doþ fo&rrot;te ȝe come &punctelev; to þe lond of bihe&slong;te
Nou was hit an e&slong;terda&ydot; &punctelev; þat al þis was ido
¶þe fowel nom his leue of hem &punctelev; & to his felawes wende þo
Þe foweles þo hit eue*. [al. time] was &punctelev; bigonne here euesong
Muriere song nemiȝte beo &punctelev; þeȝ god God silf were among
Þe monekes wende to bedde & slepe &punctelev; þo soper was ido
& þo hit was t&ydot;me of mat&ydot;ns &punctelev; hi arise þerto
¶Þe foweles sunge ek here mat&ydot;ns &punctelev; wel riȝt þo hit was t&ydot;me
& of þe sauter seide þe*. [al. om.] uers &punctelev; & siþþe also[MS. alto] p&rrot;ime
& vnderne siþþe & middai &punctelev; & afterwardes non
& eche t&ydot;de songen of þe dai &punctelev; as cri&slong;tene men scholde don
Þis monekes were in þe lond &punctelev; eiȝte w&ydot;ke also
Fo&rrot;to alþe fe&slong;te of e&slong;ter &punctelev; & of witsonedai were ido
¶Þo com atte trinite &punctelev; þis gode man to hem þer
Þat spac wiþ hem in þe lond of scheep &punctelev; & ladde aboute er
he chargede here schip su&ydot;þe wel &punctelev; mid mete & d&rrot;inke &ydot;nouȝ
& nom his leue wel hendeliche &punctelev; & aȝeward d&rrot;ouȝ
¶Þo seint b&rrot;endan Brendan was in his schip &punctelev; & his b&rrot;eþeren also
Þis fowel þat spac wiþ hem er &punctelev; wel sone com hem to
he seide ȝe habbeþ her wiþ ous &punctelev; þis heȝe fe&slong;te ibeo
Gret traua&ydot;l ȝou is to come &punctelev; er ȝe eftsone lond iseo
Ȝe schulleþ after soue monþes &punctelev; iseo a wel fair &ydot;le
Þat abbe&ydot; is icliped &punctelev; þat is hunne meni a m&ydot;le
Ȝe schulleþ beo mid holie men &punctelev; þis m&ydot;dew&ydot;nter þere
Ȝoure e&slong;ter ȝe schulle holde þer &punctelev; as ȝe dude toȝere
Vpe þe grete fisches rugge &punctelev; þer þi monekes were infere
& ȝoure e&slong;ter [be] mid ous &punctelev; riȝt as ȝe nou were
Seint b&rrot;endan Brendan a godes Godes name &punctelev; & his b&rrot;eþeren echon
In þe grete see of occian Occian &punctelev; fo&rrot;þ wende anon
Þe w&ydot;nd hem harlede vp & doun &punctelev; in per&ydot;ls meni on
So weri hi were of here l&ydot;ue &punctelev; þat hi nu&slong;te whoder gon
Four monþes hi were*. [al. wende] in þe see &punctelev; in þis grete turment]>[Here L. goes on again.]
Þat hu&ydot; ne &ydot;seiȝen noþing bote þe se &punctelev; ant þe firmament
Þo hu&ydot; &ydot;seiȝen*. [al. seie hi] fer fram heom &punctelev; ane &ydot;le ase þei it were
heo criden fa&slong;te on Ihesu cri&slong;t &punctelev; þat hu&ydot; mo&slong;ten ariuie þere
Ȝeot after þat seint Brendan &punctelev; þis &ydot;le fur&slong;t &ydot;seiȝ[MS. saiȝ]
Fourti dawes heo wenden in þe se &punctelev; er hu&ydot; comen þere neiȝ
Þat heom þouȝte heo&rrot;e lif was heom loz &punctelev; þe Monekes weren aga&slong;te
heo criden ȝeo&rrot;ne on Ihesu cri&slong;t &punctelev; and is help heo beden fa&slong;te
A lu&ydot;tel hauene and sw&ydot;þe &slong;treit &punctelev; hu&ydot; founden atþe la&slong;te
Þat vnneþes heo&rrot;e schip miȝte þerinne come &punctelev; Aunker[MS. Annker] fo&rrot;to ca&slong;te
Þis Monekes wenden alond þo &punctelev; wel longue heom þouȝte er
hu&ydot; biheolden alaboute &punctelev; murie heom þouȝte þer
Þo &ydot;seiȝen heo twe&ydot; faire wellene &punctelev; þat on was su&ydot;þe cler
And sumdel wo&rrot;i and þicke þat oþer was. &punctelev; þe Monekes ȝeoden ner
to d&rrot;inken of þat faire welle. &punctelev; seint Brendan it iseiȝ
And seide withoute leue of oþur men &punctelev; ne come ȝe nouȝt þere neiȝ
Of olde men þat hereinne beoz &punctelev; al þo&rrot;uȝ godes Godes wille[al. fo&rrot; mid gode wille]
Fo&rrot;*. [om.] heo wollez part&ydot; þarof mid us &punctelev; and þarefo&rrot;e beoz ȝeot &slong;tille
A fair old man and swiþe ho&rrot; &punctelev; aȝein heom þere cam gon
he welcomede heom faire inovȝ &punctelev; and seint Brendan he cu&slong;te anon
And ladde heom fo&rrot;th with him &punctelev; bi a wel fair wei
Aboute in man&ydot; a murie &slong;tude &punctelev; and sethþe into on Abbe&ydot;
Seint Brendan biheold aboute &punctelev; and axede ȝwat it were
And ȝwatmanere men weren þareinne &punctelev; and ho þare[al. om.] woneden þere
Stille was þis olde man &punctelev; and ne ȝaf him none Answere
Þo cam þere gon a fair couent &punctelev; and ane cro&ydot;z bifo&rrot;e heom bere
With taperes in e&ydot;þur side &punctelev; Monekes it weren echon
And &ydot;reue&slong;ted faire and in queo&rrot;copes &punctelev; aȝein heom hu&ydot; comen gon
With p&rrot;ocession faire inouȝ. &punctelev; þe Abbod bihinde com
And wel faire cu&slong;te seint Brendan &punctelev; and bi þe hond him nom
he ladde him and is monekus &punctelev; into a noble halle
And setten*. [al. sette] heom adoun alle on a rewe &punctelev; and wuchs heo&rrot;e fet alle
Of þe wo&rrot;ie welle heo&rrot;e fet he wuchs &punctelev; þat hu&ydot; er iseiȝe
Into þe fre&ydot;to&rrot;e he ladde heom þo &punctelev; and sette heom wel heiȝe
Imedlede with heo&rrot;e*. [al. his] owene couent. &punctelev; and þo heo weren alle isete
Þare cam on and seruede &punctelev; and b&rrot;ouȝte heom alle mete
And ane wel faire ȝwite lof &punctelev; he sette bitwene to & to
Ȝwite mo&rrot;en ase it of herbes were &punctelev; bifo&rrot;e heom he sette also
Swetto&rrot;e mete ne miȝte non beo &punctelev; hu&ydot; ne knewen it nouȝt on
Of þe clere welle þat hu&ydot; er iseiȝen &punctelev; þe Monekes d&rrot;onke echon
beoz nouþe glade þe Abbot seide &punctelev; and d&rrot;inkez nouþe inovȝ
In charite of þulke welle &punctelev; þat ȝe wolden er with wouȝ
Betere it is d&rrot;inke in charite &punctelev; ȝwan it is ov ib&rrot;ouȝt
Þane ȝe it þeofliche nomen &punctelev; ase ȝe hadden iþouȝt
Þis b&rrot;ed þat we eteth of &punctelev; we nuten of ȝwan it is
An &slong;traunge man eche da&ydot;e it b&rrot;inguth &punctelev; Into ovre celere iwis
We nutez nouȝt bote ope godes Godes grace &punctelev; wanne it is ib&rrot;ouȝt
Fo&rrot; hoso tru&slong;t to ihesu cri&slong;t &punctelev; him ne schal faill&ydot; nouȝt
We beoz foureanttwenti freres &punctelev; and ȝwane we beoz isete
twelf ȝwite Miches*. [al. suche loues] men b&rrot;&ydot;nguth us &punctelev; eche da&ydot;e to o&rrot;e mete
Ate fe&slong;te of eche halida&ydot;e; and ȝwan it sonenda&ydot; is
Foureandtwenti loues us comieth &punctelev; so þat euerech man hath his
Þat euerech frere of þat him leuez &punctelev; witiez to is soper
Idoublet it wo&rrot;th nouþe fo&rrot; ov &punctelev; ase ȝe iseoth wel her
Al*. [al. vo&rrot; al] o&rrot;e couent nis nouȝt here &punctelev; ake muche[al. muchedel] it hath vnete
So þat o&rrot;e louerd þo&rrot;uȝ is grace &punctelev; sent us alle mete
Fram seint paterikes Abbe&ydot;e*. [al. dai &punctelev; & seint ailbi also] &punctelev; þat in &ydot;rlonde is also
Foursco&rrot;e ȝer we habbez ibeon here &punctelev; þat no man ne cam us to
euereeft o&rrot;e louerd þo&rrot;uȝ is grace &punctelev; Ifed us hath echon
And þis weder is euere murie inouȝ &punctelev; s&ydot;knesse here nis non
And ȝwane we schullen o&rrot;e seruise don &punctelev; o&rrot;e louerd sent us liȝt
Ore taperes ne beoz noþe lasse &punctelev; þei hu&ydot; b&rrot;enne da&ydot; and n&ydot;ȝt
heo arisen op and wenden to churche &punctelev; þo heo hadden &ydot;ȝete
And twelf oþere freres heo imetten &punctelev; Inward to þe mete
hov is þis? quath seint Brendan &punctelev; ȝw&ydot; neren þeose nouȝt with us
Leoue fader quath þe Abbot &punctelev; nede it mot beo þus
Þer ne mouwen bote foureandtwenti Monekes &punctelev; in o&rrot;e freito&rrot;e beon ido
And ȝwane ȝe weren þareinne with us &punctelev; þeos ne miȝten nouȝt also
Þe ȝwile we singuth euesong &punctelev; heo schullen sitte and ete
And heo&rrot;e euesong hu&ydot; schullen s&ydot;ngue &punctelev; ȝwane heo habbez iȝet[e]
Seint b&rrot;endan Brendan biheold þat weued &punctelev; him þouȝte þat hit was al
weued and chaliz and Cruettes &punctelev; þo&rrot;uȝout cler cri&slong;tal
Seue taperes weren in þe queo&rrot; &punctelev; fo&rrot; þare ne weren non mo
And foureandtwenti segene &punctelev; þat Monekes scholden to
Fo&rrot; þare weren foureandtwenti Monekes &punctelev; and euerech hadde his
And þe Abbodes sege was &punctelev; amidde þe queo&rrot; iwis
Seint Brendan axede þe Abbode &punctelev; do seiȝe me leue b&rrot;oþur
hov holde ȝe so silence &punctelev; þat neuer on ne spekez with oþur
Ore louerd it wot þe Abbot seide &punctelev; þat[al. om.] we habbez here ibeo
Four sco&rrot;e ȝer in swuche l&ydot;ue &punctelev; ase ȝe mowen here iseo
And þare nas neuere among us alle &punctelev; &ydot;speke in none wise
Are þis t&ydot;me non oþur wo&rrot;d &punctelev; bote o&rrot;e louerdes seruise
Ne we neren neuereft in feblesse &punctelev; ne sike of us nouȝt on
Seint b&rrot;endan Brendan þo he iheo&rrot;de þis &punctelev; fo&rrot; Io&ydot;ȝe he weop anon
Leoue fader he seide &punctelev; mote we bileue here
Þov wo&slong;t wel þe Abbot seide &punctelev; ȝe ne mowen in none manere
Ne haueth o&rrot;e louerd ischewed ov wel &punctelev; ȝwat ȝe schullen do
Come þov schalt to &ydot;rlonde iwis &punctelev; and þine twelf b&rrot;eþren also
And fram þe to þe &ydot;le of Ankres &punctelev; þe þreotteoþe schal iwende
Þe fourteoþe al quic to helle &punctelev; and beon þare withouten ende
Þo cam*. [o&rrot;ig. com] þareIn a fu&ydot;ri Arewe &punctelev; at a fene&slong;tre anon
Ase þei heo fram heouene come &punctelev; and þe taperes tende echon
And flevȝ out aȝein ase heo cam In &punctelev; bi þulke fene&slong;tre þere
Þe taperes barnden longue Inov &punctelev; and noþe lasse hu&ydot; nere
Louerd cri&slong;t quath seint b&rrot;endan Brendan &punctelev; Ich wond&rrot;i In mi þouȝt
houȝ þis taperes bernez þus &punctelev; and ne waniez nouȝt
Ne ha&slong;tþou quath þe Abbod &punctelev; In þe olde lawe ifounde
hov Mo&ydot;ses sa&ydot; A þo&rrot;n berne &punctelev; fram þe toppe to þe grounde
Þe Mo&rrot;e þat þe þo&rrot;n barnde &punctelev; þe greno&rrot;e þe leues were
Ne wene&slong;tþou nouȝt þat o&rrot;e louerd beo &punctelev; ase miȝti here as þere
Þeos Monekes weren togadere &punctelev; fo&rrot;to Midew&ydot;nter was al ido
Fo&rrot;to after twelfteda&ydot; &punctelev; are hu&ydot; departeden ato
Anon to seint h&ydot;llaries Hyllaries da&ydot; &punctelev; seint Brendan fo&rrot;th iwende
With is Monekus in þe se &punctelev; þo&rrot;uȝ grace þat god God heom sende
hu&ydot; floten op and doun in so&rrot;uwe Inovȝ &punctelev; þe se heom ca&slong;te heiȝe
Fram þulke t&ydot;me fo&rrot;to in leinte &punctelev; no lond hu&ydot; ne iseiȝe
So þat aboute palmesonenda&ydot; &punctelev; heo biheolden aboute fa&slong;te
heom þouȝte heo iseiȝen swiþe fer &punctelev; ase a cloude ate la&slong;te
Þis Monekes hadden wonder þarof &punctelev; ȝwat þe cloude were
beoth &slong;tille seide seint b&rrot;endan Brendan &punctelev; ȝe habbez ibeon þere
Þare is o&rrot;e p&rrot;ocuratour &punctelev; þat muche guod us hath ido
In [þe] foulene para&ydot;s &punctelev; and In þe lond of schep also
So þat heo&rrot;e schip ate la&slong;te &punctelev; to þat &ydot;le d&rrot;ouȝ
Aschereþo&rrot;esda&ydot; hu&ydot; comen þudere &punctelev; in gret trauaile inouȝ
Þis p&rrot;ocuratour heom cam aȝein &punctelev; and welcomede heom anon
Ant cu&slong;te seint b&rrot;endan Brendan es fet &punctelev; and þe Monekes echon
And sette heom sethþe to þe soper &punctelev; fo&rrot; þe da&ydot; it wolde so
And sethþe he wuchs ho&rrot;e fet alle &punctelev; þe maunde fo&rrot;to do
hu&ydot; heolden þare heo&rrot;e maunde &punctelev; and þare heo gounnen bileue
Agode frida&ydot; al þe longue da&ydot; &punctelev; fo&rrot;to an e&slong;ter eue
An e&slong;ter eue heo&rrot;e p&rrot;ocuratour &punctelev; bad heom heo&rrot;e schip take
And heo&rrot;e resurrection &punctelev; opon þe fisches rugge make
And aftur heo&rrot;e resurrection &punctelev; he bad heom euene teo
to þe foulene para&ydot;s &punctelev; ase heo hadden er ibeo
Þis holie men wenden fo&rrot;th &punctelev; and o&rrot;e louerdes grace nome
Þat*. [al. so þat] to þis grete fischse &punctelev; þulke da&ydot;e hu&ydot; come
Þat houede ase it were a lond. &punctelev; heo&rrot;e caud&rrot;on heo founden þere
Ase heo it bileften opon is rugge &punctelev; in þat oþere ȝere
Louerd cri&slong;t þat swch a be&slong;t &punctelev; scholde houi so &slong;tille
And soffri men opon him gon &punctelev; and don al heo&rrot;e wille
Þis Monekes opon þe fisches rugge &punctelev; bileften al þe n&ydot;ȝt
And songuen mat&ydot;nes and euesong &punctelev; and sethþe þo it was liȝt
Opon is rugge hu&ydot; sounguen &punctelev; heo&rrot;e massene echon;[MS. echone]
And euere*. [MS. eueuere] houede þis muche fichs &punctelev; &slong;tille so en&ydot; &slong;ton
Þo heo&rrot;e resurrection was &punctelev; with gret honour ido
And þis Monekus hadden isongue &punctelev; heo&rrot;e Massene also
Aboute onderne of þe da&ydot;e &punctelev; to þe schipe hu&ydot; heom nome
And to þe foulene para&ydot;s &punctelev; þat ilke da&ydot; hu&ydot; come
Þo þis foules iseiȝen heom come &punctelev; hu&ydot; gonne singue echone
Aȝene&slong;t heom with gret melodie &punctelev; ase it were fo&rrot; þenone
Þe foul þat spac with [heom] er &punctelev; aȝein hem[o&rrot;ig. him] sone he d&rrot;ouȝ
þe d&rrot;em of is winguene murie was &punctelev; he welcomede heom faire &ydot;nouȝ
Ȝe Auȝten he seide o&rrot;e louerd cri&slong;t &punctelev; þonk&ydot; mid þe be&slong;te
Þat po&rrot;ueiez ou þeos four &slong;tudes &punctelev; to habben on ouwer re&slong;te
With ouwer guode p&rrot;ocratour &punctelev; ouwer maunde fo&rrot;to do
And sethþe ouwer resurrection &punctelev; ope þe fisches rugge also
And sethþe with us þis eiȝte wokes &punctelev; anon to witsonenda&ydot;
And fram Midewinter to candelemasse &punctelev; In þe &ydot;le of Abbe&ydot;.[MS. A&ydot;lbe&ydot;]
In þe se [of] Occean01 &punctelev; in gret peril ȝe schullen iwende
In trauail al þat oþur t&ydot;me &punctelev; fo&rrot;to þe seuen ȝeres ende
And sethþe þat lond of bihe&slong;te &punctelev; god God wole þat ȝe iseon
And fourti [dawes] sethþe þarinne &punctelev; In io&ydot;ȝe ȝe schullen beon
And to þe contre&ydot;e þat ȝe beoz of &punctelev; sethþe ȝe schullen iwende
Withoute trauail al aisieliche &punctelev; and þare ower lif ende
Þis holi men bilefden þare &punctelev; fo&rrot;to þe trinite
heo&rrot;e p&rrot;ocratour to hem cam &punctelev; and*. [al. þat] was euere in plente
he b&rrot;ouȝte heom mete and d&rrot;inke inouȝ &punctelev; ase he hadde er ido
And chargede heo&rrot;e schip þerewith &punctelev; and let heom wenden so
Þis holie men wenden fo&rrot;th &punctelev; ase god God heom wolde sende
Fo&rrot; godes Godes grace was with heom &punctelev; þe betere hu&ydot; miȝten wenden
Also hu&ydot; wenden In a t&ydot;me &punctelev; In &slong;trong tempe&slong;te jnouȝ[Pissis mala.]
A gret fisch hu&ydot; seiȝen and grislich &punctelev; after þe schipe he d&rrot;ouȝ
brenninde fom out of is mouth &punctelev; after heom he ca&slong;te
Þat water was herre þane heo&rrot;e schip &punctelev; bifo&rrot;e heom at eche bla&slong;te
he cam wolchi after ase an hous &punctelev; and po&rrot;siwede heom so fa&slong;te
So*. [al. so fa&slong;te] he schef with is b&rrot;eo&slong;tene &punctelev; þe Monekes weren aga&slong;te
And criden ȝeo&rrot;ne on seint b&rrot;endan Brendan &punctelev; and on o&rrot;e louerd also
After heo&rrot;e schip so sw&ydot;þe he schef &punctelev; þat he cam alme&slong;t þerto
And þo he heom hadde alme&slong;t ouertake &punctelev; [&] hu&ydot; ne tolden nouȝt of ho&rrot;e liue
An oþur fisch out of þe we&slong;t &punctelev; þare cam sw&ydot;mme bliue
he gan imete þis luþere fisch &punctelev; and smot to him fa&slong;te
Þat he fo&rrot;clef is foule bouk &punctelev; in þre part&ydot;es atþe la&slong;te
Þat ilke*. [al. & þane] we&ydot; þat he cam er &punctelev; wel euene aȝein he d&rrot;ouȝ
Þis monekes þonkeden iesu cri&slong;t &punctelev; and weren [gladde][added later; al. io&ydot;ful] &ydot;nouȝ
Longue*. [al. So longe] wenden þis gode men &punctelev; in þe se fo&rrot;th so
Þat hu&ydot; weren ofhongred so&rrot;e &punctelev; and heo&rrot;e mete was al ido
*. [Auis paradisi.]Þo cam þare fleo a lu&ydot;tel foul &punctelev; and b&rrot;ouȝte a gret bouȝ
Fol of grapus sw&ydot;þe rede &punctelev; and euene to heom he d&rrot;ouȝ.[A v. om.: þis grapes he tok s. b&rrot;endan Brendan &punctelev; þis gode man somdel louȝ.]
Þarebi heo liueden fourtene niȝt &punctelev; and hadden mete inouȝ
Þo þis grapes weren idon alle &punctelev; ofhongrede hu&ydot; weren so&rrot;e
bi þone side hu&ydot; iseiȝen an &ydot;le &punctelev; and mete þarinne mo&rrot;e
Þe &ydot;le was ful of faire treon &punctelev; and so ful was euerech bouȝ
Of swuche grapes ase hu&ydot; hadden er &punctelev; þat on þe grounde it d&rrot;ouȝ
Seint b&rrot;endan Brendan wende op of þis schip &punctelev; þe grapes he nam fa&slong;te
And bar into þe schipe to libbe þerbi &punctelev; þat fourti dawes it[al. ila&slong;te] la&slong;te
Sone þare cam a gr&ydot;p fleoinde &punctelev; after heom in þe se
And asaillede heom in heo&rrot;e schip &punctelev; and fondede heom to sle
Þis Monekes criden deolfolliche &punctelev; and tolden lu&ydot;te of heo&rrot;e l&ydot;ue
Þo iseiȝen hu&ydot; come þat lu&ydot;tel foul &punctelev; toward hem wel bliue
Þat heom*. [al. om.] in foulene para&ydot;s &punctelev; so ofte heom hadde irad
Þo seint b&rrot;endan Brendan isaiȝ him*. [MS. heom] come &punctelev; he nas nouȝt a lu&ydot;tel glad
Þis lu&ydot;tel [foul]*. [added later.] smot to þis gr&ydot;p &punctelev; and nam is dunt so heiȝe
And at þe fur&slong;te dunte &punctelev; he smot out e&ydot;þur e&ydot;ȝen
Sone he aslouȝ þis luþere be&slong;t &punctelev; þat he fel doun into þe se
Þing þat god God wole habbe iwu&slong;t &punctelev; ne schal it no wiȝt[o&rrot;ig. man al. þing] sle
Þis holie Men wenden in þe se &punctelev; aboute here and þere
In on of þe four &slong;tudes &punctelev; þe he&ydot;ȝe fe&slong;tes hu&ydot; were
In a seint peteres Peteres da&ydot; &punctelev; gret fe&slong;te hu&ydot; maden with heo&rrot;e tounge
And swiþe murie of seint peter &punctelev; In þe se hu&ydot; sounge
In a &slong;tude of þe se &punctelev; so cler þe se hu&ydot; founde
Aboute heo iseiȝen in eche side &punctelev; clerliche to þe grounde
heom þouȝte þe ground was on eche half*. [al. iheled was] &punctelev; with fisch al on hepe
Þis Monekes beden seint b&rrot;endan Brendan &punctelev; þat he softe speke
So þat he ne aweiȝte nouȝt þe fisches &punctelev; la&slong;te hu&ydot; heo&rrot;e schip b&rrot;eke
Alle þe fisches leiȝen &slong;tille &punctelev; ase þei heo weren aslepe.[This v. follows after 448 in the other MSS.]
beo ȝe aferde quath seint b&rrot;endan Brendan &punctelev; ȝwarof beo ȝe ad&rrot;ad
Opon þe mai&slong;teres rugge of alle fisches &punctelev; ȝe habbez ibeon wel glad
And fu&ydot;r imaked opon is rugge &punctelev; and doth fram ȝere to ȝere
Þis holie Man þe luddere song &punctelev; fo&rrot; þes ones[al. þen one] ase þei it were
Þe fisches &slong;turten op with þis song &punctelev; ase þei hu&ydot; awoken aslepe
And comen aboute þis monekes &punctelev; alle to one hepe
So þicke hu&ydot; floten bi eche side &punctelev; no water man ne iseiȝ[MS. sạeiȝ]
And bisetten þat schip alaboute &punctelev; Ake no water[al. ac hi] ne cam þare neiȝ
So þicke hu&ydot; weren aboute þis schip &punctelev; And euere s&ydot;weden it so
Þe ȝw&ydot;le b&rrot;endan Brendan is Masse song &punctelev; fo&rrot;to heo was al ido
And þo þe Masse was al*. [MS. all] ido &punctelev; ech fisch wende in is ende
Muche ȝwounder man ma&ydot; iseo &punctelev; þat wide wole iwende
Þe w&ydot;nd was boþe &slong;trong and &slong;tif &punctelev; and d&rrot;of heo&rrot;e schip so fa&slong;te
Also feo&rrot; ase heo miȝten seuen&ydot;ȝt wenden &punctelev; þat clere water ila&slong;te
þat heo iseiȝen in þe se &punctelev; ase clerliche ase hu&ydot; miȝten alonde
gret wonder hadden þis gode Men &punctelev; and þonkeden godes Godes sonde
Þo cam sone a souþerne w&ydot;nd &punctelev; and no&rrot;thþeward d&rrot;of heom fa&slong;te
Riȝt euene with heom he was &punctelev; and eiȝte dawes he la&slong;te
Þo iseiȝen hu&ydot; feo&rrot; in þe no&rrot;th &punctelev; a lond deo&rrot;k inouȝ
Smoke &slong;t&ydot;nkinde foule*. [al. smokie as it sm&ydot;thes were] &punctelev; and þuderward heo&rrot;e schip d&rrot;ouȝ
Þo iheo&rrot;den heo gret blow&ydot;nge &punctelev; of manie beolies þere
And gret bet&ydot;nge and no&ydot;se inouȝ &punctelev; þond&rrot;e ase þei it were
þo was b&rrot;endan Brendan so&rrot;i jnouȝ &punctelev; and blessede him wel fa&slong;te
Þo cam þare out a luþer w&ydot;ȝt &punctelev; ful Atelich ate la&slong;te
Þo&rrot;uout swart and b&rrot;enninde &punctelev; ope heom is eiȝene he ca&slong;te
And to&rrot;nede him anon aȝen &punctelev; þis Monekes weren aga&slong;te
Þat luþere wiȝt ȝaf a cri &punctelev; þat Men miȝten iheo&rrot;e him wide
Þo come þare out swuche schrewes mo &punctelev; þicke on eche side
With tongen*. [o&rrot;ig. tongene] and with hameres &punctelev; b&rrot;enninde mani on
Opon þe watere heo o&rrot;nen fa&slong;te*. [al. To þe b&rrot;imme h. o. of þe se] &punctelev; After þat schip echon
þo hu&ydot; ne miȝten þareneiȝ come &punctelev; hu&ydot; gounnen to ȝeolle fa&slong;te
heo&rrot;e hameres al b&rrot;enninde &punctelev; after þis men hu&ydot; ca&slong;ten
Þat men ne miȝten noþing bote fu&ydot;r &punctelev; noþer iseo ne hu&ydot;re;[MS. hẹuọ&ydot;re]
Þe se was b&rrot;enninde alab&rrot;od &punctelev; ase þei heo were afu&ydot;re
euerech ca&slong;te is owel op oþur &punctelev; and some hu&ydot; þrewen an heiȝ
hu&ydot; þrewen alle aboute þat schip &punctelev; ake non ne cam þareneiȝ
Ate la&slong;te heo to&rrot;neden alle aȝein &punctelev; þo hu&ydot; ne spedden nouȝt þere
And al þat lond þouȝte of heom &punctelev; afu&ydot;re ase þei it were
And al þe se þare aboute &punctelev; barnde and smokede fa&slong;te
Strong was þe &slong;tunch and þe smoke &punctelev; and longe iwis it la&slong;te
Þo þe smoke*. [al. monekes] was sumdel feo&rrot; &punctelev; þat heo ne iseiȝen non mo&rrot;e
Ȝeot heo iheo&rrot;den heo&rrot;e ȝeollinge &punctelev; þe þeoues weopen so&rrot;e
hou þinchez ou quath b&rrot;endan Brendan &punctelev; was þis a murie pas
We nellez nonmo&rrot;e come þareneiȝ &punctelev; þat on ende of helle it was
And þe feondes hopeden su&ydot;þe wel &punctelev; habbe ihaued a wel god God cas
Ake ihered beo swete ihesu cri&slong;t &punctelev; hu&ydot; ca&slong;ten Aumbes as
Þe souþerne wind la&slong;te ȝu&ydot;t &punctelev; and ȝu&ydot;t d&rrot;of heom fo&rrot;th
So þat hu&ydot; iseiȝen ane hul &punctelev; wel feo&rrot; in þe no&rrot;th
glowinde and b&rrot;enninde smoke &punctelev; gret &slong;tunch so was þere
Þe leiȝe &slong;tod op an heiȝ &punctelev; ase þei it a wal were
Ȝif þare was muche in þat oþur &slong;tude &punctelev; þare was ȝeot wel mo&rrot;e
On of þe monekes þo bigan &punctelev; to weope and ȝeollen so&rrot;e
Fo&rrot; is t&ydot;me was þo icome &punctelev; he ne miȝte no leng bileue
he hupte out of þat schip &punctelev; and amidde þe se he gan weue
And o&rrot;n fa&slong;te opon þe watere &punctelev; toward þat ilke fu&ydot;re
he cride ȝeo&rrot;ne and ȝal deolfulliche &punctelev; þat gret deol it was to hu&ydot;re
Alas he seide mi wrechche lijf! &punctelev; fo&rrot; nou i seo min ende
In io&ydot;e ich habbe with ou ibeo &punctelev; ake ine ma&ydot; nouȝt aȝen wende
Aco&rrot;sed beo þat me bar &punctelev; and þe t&ydot;me þat ich was ibo&rrot;e
And þe fader þat me biȝat! &punctelev; fo&rrot; ich am nouþe fo&rrot;lo&rrot;e
Þe feondes comen him aȝein &punctelev; and nomen þat wrechche fa&slong;te
And defouleden him &slong;tronge Inouȝ &punctelev; and amidde þe fu&ydot;re him ca&slong;te
Þo fond he soth þat seint b&rrot;endan Brendan &punctelev; seide þo he out wende
him failede grace houso it was &punctelev; his sunnes fo&rrot;to amende
So fa&slong;te barnde þe Monta&ydot;ne &punctelev; þat noþing hu&ydot; ne iseiȝe
Þe ȝu&ydot;t heo weren feo&rrot; þarefram &punctelev; noþing bote le&ydot;ȝe
Þo to&rrot;nede þe w&ydot;nd into þe No&rrot;th &punctelev; and d&rrot;of heom southward fa&slong;te
In þulke side &slong;tronge Inouȝ &punctelev; þat seuenNiȝt fulle he la&slong;te
So longe hu&ydot; wenden euene south &punctelev; þat hu&ydot; iseiȝen at þen ende [Judas.]
One harde roche In þe se &punctelev; and þe se þareouer wende
Þareouer þe se ca&slong;te ilome &punctelev; and ofte he was bar
Ant þo heo comen þe roche neiȝ &punctelev; of a go&slong;t heo weren iwar
heo iseiȝe onouewarde þe roche sitte &punctelev; ȝwane þe se withd&rrot;ouȝ
A wrechche go&slong;t naked and bar &punctelev; in &slong;tronge meseise jnouȝ
Aboue him was a cloth itild*. [al. teid] &punctelev; with tweie tonguene fa&slong;te
to is chin tilde þe neoþer ende &punctelev; þe w&ydot;nd it wide ca&slong;te
Þat euere ȝwane þat water him withd&rrot;ouȝ &punctelev; þat cloth þat heng heiȝe
beot him*. [al. om.] ase þe w&ydot;nd him blevȝ &punctelev; þat wrechche go&slong;t[al. om.] in þen eiȝe
Þe wawes of þe se beoten also &punctelev; bifo&rrot;e and bih&ydot;nde
A ȝeomero&rrot;e go&slong;t þane he was &punctelev; ne miȝte no man finde
Seint Brendan him bad a godes Godes name &punctelev; telle ȝwat he were
And ȝwat he hadde o&rrot;e louerd misdon &punctelev; and ȝwi he sete þere
Ich am he seide a deolful go&slong;t &punctelev; ich hote wrechche Iudas
Þat o&rrot;e louerd fo&rrot; panewes solde &punctelev; and on eo&rrot;þe with him was
Þis nis nouȝt mi riȝte &slong;tude &punctelev; ake o&rrot;e louerd doth me grace
to habben mi para&ydot;s &punctelev; here in þis place
Fo&rrot; no guodnesse þat ich dude &punctelev; bote o&rrot;e louerdes o&rrot;e
Ine habbe nouȝt so muche pine &punctelev; þat ich nere wurþe mo&rrot;e
Fo&rrot; in þe b&rrot;enn&ydot;nde hulle &punctelev; þat ech of eov isaiȝ
Mi riȝte is to b&rrot;ennen Inne &punctelev; boþe n&ydot;ȝt and da&ydot;ȝ
Þare ich was þis ȝeondere daiȝ &punctelev; þo ower b&rrot;oþer þudere cam
And was into pine ilad &punctelev; and þare hadde is dom
Þarefo&rrot;e helle was so glad*. [o&rrot;ig. gled] &punctelev; and makede so grete leiȝe
Fo&rrot; þat he was þudere icome &punctelev; and so neiȝ him[al. þat ȝe so ver] iseiȝe
So hu&ydot; doz ȝwane ani soule &punctelev; is fo&rrot;me&slong;t þudere icome
Þo&rrot;uȝ godes Godes heiȝe milce &punctelev; þarefram ich am inome
Fo&rrot; here ich am euerech sonenda&ydot; &punctelev; and fram saterda&ydot;ȝes eue
Fo&rrot;to euensong t&ydot;me þane sonenda&ydot; &punctelev; here i schal bileue
Ant at Midewinter also &punctelev; fo&rrot;to twelftedai beo ido
Ant fram þe bigu&ydot;nninge of e&slong;tur &punctelev; þat ȝwitsonenda&ydot; come also
Ant also at o&rrot;e lauedi fe&slong;tes &punctelev; so ful of milce heo is
Ake alle oþure t&ydot;mene &punctelev; In helle ich am iwis
With pilatus Pilatus . ant with heo&rrot;oudus Heoroudus &punctelev; and also with[al. Anne and]
ca&ydot;phas Cayphas
Aco&rrot;sed beo þe t&ydot;me &punctelev; þat ich ibo&rrot;en was
Ich bidde þe fo&rrot; þe loue of god God &punctelev; fonde on alle wise
Fo&rrot;to bileuen*. [al. þat ich bileue] here al þis[al. niȝt] &punctelev; þat þe sonne arise
And þat ȝe w&ydot;ten me fram þe feondes &punctelev; þat sone comieth aftur me
Seint Brendan seide þo&rrot;uȝ godes Godes grace &punctelev; we schullen schilde þe
tel me nouþe ȝwat is þat cloth &punctelev; þat so heiȝe hanguth her[o&rrot;ig. here]
Þo ich was on eo&rrot;þe &punctelev; and godes Godes panewes ber
Þis cloth ich ȝaf a musel &punctelev; and min owene it nas nouȝt
Fo&rrot; it was with o&rrot;e louerdes panes &punctelev; ant mine felawes ibouȝt
Ant fo&rrot; ich it ȝaf fo&rrot; godes Godes loue &punctelev; nouþe it is me bifo&rrot;e
So lu&ydot;te ne schal man fo&rrot; him do &punctelev; þat schulle beo ilo&rrot;e
Fo&rrot; it was of oþur mannes &punctelev; ase ich me under&slong;tod
Þei it hang&ydot; bifo&rrot;e me &punctelev; it doth me mo&rrot;e harm þane guod
In mine eiȝene it bat so&rrot;e &punctelev; ant doth hem harm inouȝ
Man mai iseo ȝwuch it is &punctelev; to ȝ&ydot;uen oþur mannes þing with wouȝ
As wollez manie of þis riche men &punctelev; with onriȝte al da&ydot; take
Of pouere men here ant þer &punctelev; and almesse þarof make
Þat heo doth fo&rrot; godes Godes loue &punctelev; ne schal nouȝt beo fo&rrot;ȝite
Ake to pine it heom turne schal &punctelev; ant þat hu&ydot; schullen iwite
Þe tonguene also quath Iudas &punctelev; þat ȝe so heiȝe iseoth
twe&ydot;e p&rrot;eo&slong;tes ich ȝaf on eo&rrot;þe &punctelev; and þarefo&rrot;e here heo beoth
Fo&rrot; man schal clanliche ech þing finde &punctelev; þat he doth fo&rrot; is loue
Þe &slong;ton þat ich opon sitte &punctelev; and makez me sitte aboue
In one weiȝe ich h&ydot;ne fond &punctelev; þare non neode nas no &slong;ton
In a fenni dich ich it ca&slong;te &punctelev; þat men miȝten þareouer gon
Fewe goddedes ich haue idon &punctelev; of ȝwan ich nouþe ma&ydot; telle
Nis non so lu&ydot;te þat man ne ma&ydot; f&ydot;nde &punctelev; in heuene oþur in helle
Þo it was .eue. þe sonenda&ydot; &punctelev; þe feondes comen bla&slong;te
Fo&rrot;to leden to helle þat so&rrot;i go&slong;t &punctelev; hu&ydot; weopen ant ȝollen fa&slong;te
Wend heonne heo seiden þou gode*. [al. godes Godes ] man &punctelev; þou na&slong;t nouȝt here to done
Lat us habbe o&rrot;e felawe &punctelev; ant to helle leden him sone
Fo&rrot; we ne do&rrot;ren o&rrot;e ma&ydot;&slong;ter iseo &punctelev; are we him[MS. him him] habben ib&rrot;ouȝt
Þou wend fram him fo&rrot; it is t&ydot;me &punctelev; and ne lete us nouȝt
Ich ne lette ov nouȝt quath seint b&rrot;endan Brendan &punctelev; to don ouwer me&slong;ter
Ake doth o&rrot;e louerd iesu cri&slong;t &punctelev; þat is of mo&rrot;e pouwer
hou dar&slong;t þou þe feon[des] seide &punctelev; bifo&rrot;e him nemme is name
Ne bitra&ydot;de he him and solde him also &punctelev; to deþe with grete schame
Seint Brendan seide in his name &punctelev; ich hote ov ase ich ma&ydot;
Þat ȝe ne derien him ton&ydot;ȝt &punctelev; are tomo&rrot;ewe þat hit beo da&ydot;
Reuliche þe feondes ȝollen þo &punctelev; ant hamward gonne fleo
Iudas þonkede reufolliche &punctelev; þat it was deol to seo
Amo&rrot;ewe anon so þat it was da&ydot; &punctelev; þe feondes comen bla&slong;te
Gr&ydot;sliche heo ȝollen ant weopen &punctelev; ant gonnen to chide fa&slong;te
Awe&ydot; hu&ydot; seiden gode man &punctelev; aco&rrot;sed beo þe &slong;tounde
Þat þou come here us so neiȝ &punctelev; and þat we þe here founde
Ore Mai&slong;ter us haueth ip&ydot;ned &punctelev; bitterliche al þis n&ydot;ȝt
Ant sw&ydot;þe &slong;trongue fo&rrot; we ne b&rrot;ouȝten &punctelev; with us þis so&rrot;ie wiȝt
Ake we wollez þeos six dawes &punctelev; doubli al is wo
And so we wollez awreken us &punctelev; fo&rrot; on himsulf it schal go
Þat wrechche go&slong;t quakede þo &punctelev; þat reuþe it was to seo oþur telle
Þe fendes nomen þo þis go&slong;t &punctelev; ant ladden into helle
Ant seint Brendan hem fo&rrot;bed &punctelev; In o&rrot;e louerdes name
Þat heo ne scholden fo&rrot; þat n&ydot;ȝt &punctelev; don him þe mo&rrot;e schame
Seint Brendan and is Monekus &punctelev; In þe se fo&rrot;th wende
Þre dawes euene south &punctelev; ase o&rrot;e louerd hem grace[al. om.] sende
Þe feo&rrot;þe dai heo iseiȝen ane &ydot;le &punctelev; albi souþe an heiȝ
Seint Brendan siȝte so&rrot;e &punctelev; þo he þat [&ydot;le] iseiȝ
Powel þe heremite &punctelev; is in þe &ydot;le þat ich iseo
here he haueth withoute mete &punctelev; fourti ȝer ibeo
Þo heo comen to þis &ydot;le &punctelev; heo wenden in echon
Þis heremite þat was so old man &punctelev; aȝein hem cam anon
his her tilde doun to is fet &punctelev; of berde and of heued
and helede is bodi alaboute &punctelev; riȝt nouȝt þare nas bar bileued
None oþur cloþes nadde he on &punctelev; is limes weren al ho&rrot;e
Brendan &slong;tod and biheold &punctelev; and weop swiþe so&rrot;e[A v. om.: Alas he sede ichabbe so ȝare: in &slong;tude of monek ibe]
And nouþe In liue of Aungele &punctelev; ane man ich iseo
beo &slong;tille quath þe hermite &punctelev; fo&rrot; god God doth wel bi þe
Fo&rrot; he schewez þe mo&rrot;e þane ani oþur &punctelev; of is p&rrot;iuete
Fo&rrot; a Monek liuez muche &punctelev; bi swunche of mannes[al. is owe] honde
Ant þou liue&slong;t bi godes Godes grace &punctelev; ant þo&rrot;uȝ is owene sonde
In þe Abbe&ydot;e of seint paterich Paterich &punctelev; Monek ich was iwis
And of is churche a wardein &punctelev; þare is purgato&rrot;ie is
A da&ydot; þare cam a man to me &punctelev; ich eschte him ȝwat he were
he seide ich am þin Abbot &punctelev; ne haue of me no fere
Non oþur man þane seint paterik Paterik &punctelev; min Abbot nis ich sede
Ich it am quath he aȝein &punctelev; ne haue of me no d&rrot;ede
tomo&rrot;ewe he seide ȝwane it is da&ydot; &punctelev; to þe se þou mo&slong;t iwende
Alȝare þou schalt finde a schip &punctelev; þat god God þe wole sende
Ant do þe fo&rrot;th in þe se &punctelev; in þine schipe wide
hit wole þe lede to þe &slong;tude &punctelev; þare þou schalt abide.
Sone mo&rrot;ewe ich oup aros &punctelev; to don is holie bone
And þo ich cam to þe se &punctelev; þat schip ich fond wel sone
Mid me ich bad*. [r. let] þat schip iwo&rrot;þe &punctelev; wel euene fo&rrot;th it wende
Þe seuenþe dai to þis &ydot;le &punctelev; o&rrot;e louerd me h&ydot;dere sende
Þo ich was out of þat schip &punctelev; þane wei anon ich[al. aȝen it] nam
Riȝt euene þo&rrot;uȝ godes Godes grace &punctelev; so þat ich*. [al. riȝt as it] hidere cam.
Elinge ich ȝeode here al one &punctelev; confo&rrot;t nadich non
So þat on is hindo&rrot;e fet &punctelev; An .Otur. þare cam gon
Bitwene is fo&rrot;þere fet he b&rrot;ouȝte &punctelev; a fu&ydot;rIre ant a &slong;ton
Þarewith to smite me fu&ydot;r &punctelev; and fisch he b&rrot;ouȝte sethþe guod won
Þis [otur] wende sone aȝein. &punctelev; ich makede me fu&ydot;r fa&slong;te
Ant seth me fisch a godes Godes name &punctelev; þre da&ydot;es it ila&slong;te
So þat euere þene þridde da&ydot; &punctelev; þis .Otur. to me d&rrot;ouȝ
And b&rrot;ouȝte me mete þat ich hadde &punctelev; þre dawes þaron inouȝ
Watur of þis harde &slong;tone &punctelev; þo&rrot;uȝ o&rrot;e louerdes sonde
Þare sp&rrot;ong out of eche da&ydot;e*. [al. ech sonedai] &punctelev; to d&rrot;inke and wasche min honde
Þis welle bigan fur&slong;t hire to schewen &punctelev; þat þou miȝt iseo
here*. [al. þo] ich hadde[MS. habbe] þritti winter &punctelev; In swuche liue ibeo;[both vv. are transp. in other MS.]
bi þis welle ich habbe Ileoued &punctelev; fourti ȝer and on
And fifti ȝer ich was old &punctelev; are ich gan hidere gon
So þat of an hond&rrot;ed ȝer &punctelev; and twenti ȝer þareto
Ich am nouþe bi þis time &punctelev; o&rrot;e louerd is wille bi me do
And mi deth ich abide here &punctelev; ȝwane god God it wole sende
Ȝwanne mi louerd wole þat ich come to him &punctelev; and of þis wo&rrot;ld iwende
Ake nim with þe of þis watur &punctelev; þat þou ha&slong;t neode to
And wiend þe fo&rrot;th in þe se &punctelev; fo&rrot; þi wei nis nouȝt al ido
Fo&rrot; þou schalt ȝeot in þe se &punctelev; fourti dawes fare
And þanne þou schalt þine E&slong;ter holde &punctelev; ase þou ha&slong;t idon are
And fram þanne þou schalt wiende fo&rrot;th &punctelev; to þe londe of bihe&slong;te
And þare þou schalt fourti dawes &punctelev; bileuen atþe le&slong;te
And to þin owene londe aȝein &punctelev; þou schalt wiende so
Þis guode men with deol inouȝ &punctelev; þus departeden atwo
Þis holie men wenden hem fo&rrot;th &punctelev; in tempe&slong;te[al. in þe se] wel fa&slong;te
Fourti dawes euene south &punctelev; þe ȝwile þat leinte ila&slong;te
to heo&rrot;e guode p&rrot;ocratour &punctelev; an e&slong;ter eue hu&ydot; come
With heom he made ioie inouȝ &punctelev; ase he dude er ilome
he ladde heom to þis grete fisch. &punctelev; þudere hu&ydot; comen an eue
Þe E&slong;ter niȝt fo&rrot;to amo&rrot;uwe &punctelev; þare hu&ydot; gounne bileue
Þare hu&ydot; songuen heo&rrot;e mat&ydot;nes &punctelev; and heo&rrot;e masse also
Þe fisch bigan to meouen him &punctelev; þo þe masse was al ido
And bar þis Monekes fo&rrot;th with him &punctelev; And swam swiþe fa&slong;te
In þe se wel &slong;tu&ydot;rneliche &punctelev; þe monekes weren aga&slong;te
A wonder þing it was to seo &punctelev; hoso it hadde iseiȝe
A so gret be&slong;t aboute wiende &punctelev; ase it were a gret contreie
Riȝt to foulene parais &punctelev; þis monekes he ladde echon
And sette heom up hole and sounde &punctelev; and wende aȝein anon
Þis monekes þo hu&ydot; þudere comen &punctelev; wel glade and bliþe hu&ydot; were
Fo&rrot;to aftur þe trinite &punctelev; hu&ydot; bilefden þere
Fo&rrot; heo&rrot;e guode p&rrot;ocuratour &punctelev; þulke t&ydot;me b&rrot;ouȝte heom mete and d&rrot;ink inouȝ
Ase he hadde er ido &punctelev; into heo&rrot;e schip he it d&rrot;ouȝ
And also he wende fo&rrot;th with heom &punctelev; ȝwodereso god God heom sende
Riȝt euene toward þe e&slong;t &punctelev; fourti da&ydot;es hu&ydot; wende
Þo þe fourti daiȝes weren agon &punctelev; hit gan to hauli fa&slong;te
A wel deo&rrot;k mij&slong;t þare com also &punctelev; þat swiþe longue ila&slong;te
beoth glade seide þis p&rrot;ocuratour &punctelev; and makiez grete fe&slong;te
Fo&rrot; ichot wel þat ȝe beoth &punctelev; in*. [al. nei] þe londe of bihe&slong;te
Þo hu&ydot; comen out of þis Mij&slong;t &punctelev; and miȝten aboute iseo
In*. [al. vnder] þe faire&slong;te lond hu&ydot; weren &punctelev; þat euere miȝte beo
So cler and so liȝt it was &punctelev; þat Io&ydot;e þare was Inouȝ
Treon þare weren fulle of fru&ydot;t &punctelev; wel þicke euerech bouȝ
Þicke it was iset with treon &punctelev; þe treon wel faire were[al. & þe treon þicke bere]
Þe Applene weren ripe inouȝ &punctelev; riȝt ase it herue&slong;t were
Fourti dawes in þis londe &punctelev; aboute hu&ydot; gounne iwiende
In none half hu&ydot; ne miȝten finde &punctelev; of þis lond non ende
hit was eueremo&rrot;e da&ydot; &punctelev; heom þouȝte and neueremo&rrot;e n&ydot;ȝt
hu&ydot; ne founden in none &slong;tude &punctelev; neuere so muche liȝt
Þe e&ydot;r was euere in o &slong;tat &punctelev; naþur to hot ne to cold
Ȝwat [ioie] hu&ydot; þere founden &punctelev; ne ma&ydot; neuere beon itold
So þat hu&ydot; comen to a fair watur. &punctelev; hu&ydot; nolden nouȝt ouer iwiende. [A v. om.: Ac ouer hi miȝte þe lond ise &punctelev; vair wiþouten ende.]
Þo cam to heom a ȝonglich man &punctelev; swiþe fair and hiende
Fairo&rrot;e ne miȝte neuere non beo &punctelev; ase god God him gan þare[MS. þure] siende
he welcomede euerech bi is name &punctelev; and cu&slong;te heom echon
Faire he honourede seint Brendan &punctelev; and on is hond him nam anon
Lo he seide here þe lond &punctelev; þat ȝe habbez isouȝt so wide
Fo&rrot; o&rrot;e louerd nele nouȝt &punctelev; þat ȝe hereInne longue þus abide
Ake ȝe schullen in þe se &punctelev; is p&rrot;iuetez iseo[These vv. are co&rrot;rupt.]
Chargiez ower schip with of þis fru&ydot;t &punctelev; fo&rrot; ȝe ne mouwen no leng here beo
to seint Brendan he seide And spak &punctelev; þis ȝounge man fair and hende &punctelev; [This v. al. om.]
Þou mo&slong;t to þin owene lond &punctelev; aȝeinward anon iwiende
Fo&rrot; þou schalt sone out of þis wo&rrot;ld &punctelev; þi lijf is neiȝ atþende
Þis watur þat ȝe here iseoth &punctelev; delez þis wo&rrot;ld atwo
Þeos half ou þinchez fair inovȝ &punctelev; and biȝeonde half also
Ȝe ne mouwen nouȝt comen aȝend[MS. ȝende] half &punctelev; fo&rrot; it[is] nis nouȝt riȝt
Ake þis fru&ydot;t is euere iliche ripe &punctelev; and þis lond iliche b&rrot;iȝt
And ȝwane o&rrot;e louerd echemanere men &punctelev; to him haueth id&rrot;awe
And ȝwane allemanere men knowez him &punctelev; and vnder&slong;tondez is lawe
Þat lond he wole þanne schewe &punctelev; toward þe wo&rrot;ldes ende
heom þat beth to him ico&rrot;e &punctelev; are hu&ydot; heonnes iwiende
Seint Brendan a[n]d is Monekes &punctelev; of þis fru&ydot;t token fa&slong;te
And of p&rrot;eciouse &slong;tones also &punctelev; and into ho&rrot;e schipe it ca&slong;te
And faire and wel heo&rrot;e leue nomen &punctelev; þo al þis was ido
And with wop and so&rrot; and deol inov &punctelev; departeden atwo
And wenden hamward in þe se &punctelev; ase o&rrot;e louerd heom sende
Wel sonere ich wot hom hu&ydot; come &punctelev; þane hu&ydot; outward wende
heo&rrot;e b&rrot;eþren þo hu&ydot; comen hom &punctelev; Io&ydot;fule weren inouȝ
Seint Brendan þe holie man &punctelev; sone to deþe d&rrot;ouȝ
Fo&rrot; neueref[t] aftur þulke t&ydot;me &punctelev; of þe wo&rrot;ld he ne rouȝte
Bote as a man of an oþur wo&rrot;lde &punctelev; and ase he were in þouȝte
And deide sone in &ydot;rlaunde &punctelev; aftur þulke &slong;tounde
Mani fair miracle men habbez sethþe &punctelev; fo&rrot; him þare ifounde
And a fair Abbeie þare is are[r]d &punctelev; ase is bodi was ido
God b&rrot;ingue us to þulke Io&ydot;e &punctelev; þat is soule wende to. AmeN.[Fol. 110 b is left vacant.]
